caption_text: The effect of sample weight on the conversion of anthracene into PI is given in Fig. 1 for reaction at 525°C for l h under 6.9 MPa N3. There is a mono- tonic increase in conversion with increase in sample weight. This is in contrast to expected behavior in the presence of mass transfer effects.

caption_text: The data of Fig. 1 were therefore expressed on the basis of conversion of liquid anthracene into pyridine insolubles. As shown in Fig. 3, the data then displayed independency of sample weight. This is consistent with, but not proof of, the absence of significant mass transfer effects.

caption_text: The data of Fig. 1 were obtained experimentally using a reactor rocking frequency of 60 cy clés / min. This is sufficient to ensure that the conversion to PI was independent of the rocking frequency, as shown in Fig. 4. The yield was lower in the absence of agitation for both 2 and 4 g samples of anthracene, A.

caption_text: A comparison of data obtained for coking runs at 510°C with and without the applied N2 pressure is given in Fig. 5. No detectable difference was observed between the two cases with respect to the formation of PI. It has been established theoretically that using an inert gas to compress a liquid causes an increase in its vapor pressure[23].

caption_text: 3.3 Kinetic data Data for the conversion of anthracene into PI are given in Fig. 6 as a function of isothermal reaction time and temperature. Conversion increases mono- tonically with increase in time at reaction tempera- ture. In addition, for a specified reaction time, conversion increases with reaction temperature over the range 465 to 525°C.

caption_text: This ap- parent induction time is temperature-dependent as shown in Fig. 7. The value of t, increases with de- crease in the reaction temperature from 525 to 445°C. One interpretation of the apparent induction time is that it is the time required to reduce the concentration of anthracene to a fraction, N, of its initial value.

caption_text: A plot of In (, against Ï./T for the coking of anthracene in the liquid phase under 6.9 MPa N3 is given in Fig. 8. The correlation coefficient associated with a least-squares analysis is 0.999, in- dicating a good fit of the data by a straight line. The apparent activation energy was determined to be 40 kcal/mole with a standard deviation of 1 kcal/mole.

caption_text: A test plot for the first-order kinetics for the conversion of anthracene into PI under 6.9 MPa N; in the liquid phase is given in Fig. 9 for temperatures between 465 and 525°C. Correlation coefficients associated with a least-squares analysis are given in Table 2. The reasonably high values indicate good fitting of the data by straight lines.
raw_window: A test plot for the first-order kinetics for the conversion of anthracene into PI under 6.9 MPa N; in the liquid phase is given in Fig. 9 for temperatures between 465 and 525°C.

The reasonably high values indicate good fitting of the data by straight lines.

caption_text: First-order rate constants, calculated from the slopes in Fig. 9, are also given in Table 2. Conceptually, first-order behavior indicates that, once the formation of PI has been initiated, the rate of formation of additional PI is proportional to the concentration of material not yet converted to PI. Unconverted material could include intermediate products, as well as unreacted anthracene.

caption_text: An Arrhenius plot, based on the data of Table 2, is given in Fig. 10. The apparent activation energy for the formation of PI was cal- culated to be 46 kcal / mole. The pre-exponential fac- tor was 4 x 109 s~1.
